summary: Email chain between US Department of Justice officials and UK Home Office officials discussing challenges in obtaining an interview with a material witness (referred to as 'Material Witness PA') via Mutual Legal Assistance (MLA) treaty. The discussion focuses on UK concerns about exhausting voluntary cooperation avenues before formal MLA requests, potential judicial review by the witness's lawyers (Blackfords), and lack of trust between the US case team and the witness's counsel.

persons.name: Dawn Browne
persons.context: UKCA official involved in discussions about the MLA request and voluntary interview procedures; explained UK concerns about judicial review.

persons.name: Philomena Creffield
persons.role: Deputy Director & Head of UK Central Authority
persons.context: Senior UK Home Office official corresponding with US DOJ about the MLA request timeline and investigation status.

persons.name: Julian Gibbs
persons.context: UKCA official copied on email correspondence regarding the Material Witness PA matter.

connections.description: Bloxsome represents the material witness as counsel from Blackfords law firm.
US DOJ official communicating with UK Home Office official about MLA treaty procedures and witness interview coordination.
Significant mutual lack of trust between US prosecutors and the witness's law firm regarding voluntary cooperation.

events.title: MLA Request Discussions
events.description: Ongoing discussions between US DOJ and UK Home Office about executing a Mutual Legal Assistance request to interview a material witness.

events.title: Blackfords Cease Cooperation
events.description: Blackfords law firm sent written correspondence stating 'there is no purpose to be served in continuing to try to assist further' in the investigation.

events.title: Voluntary Cooperation Offer
events.description: Blackfords offered voluntary cooperation for their client in early June, which UK officials cite as reason to exhaust informal avenues before MLA.

locations: Home Office, 2nd Floor, Peel Building, 2 Marsham Street, London SW1P 4DF
keyFacts: UK Home Office officials are concerned about potential judicial review litigation from Blackfords law firm if they don't exhaust voluntary cooperation avenues before proceeding with MLA request.
There is a 'significant mutual lack of trust' between the US case team and Blackfords law firm, making voluntary interview outside MLA context unlikely.
The material witness's team has offered voluntary cooperation multiple times, including in early June 2020, which complicates the MLA process.
US officials argue that requiring exhaustion of informal avenues conflicts with the US-UK MLA treaty and would affect many cases going forward.
The witness is referred to as 'Material Witness PA' and the investigation involves questions about both Epstein and another subject where facts are described as 'pretty thin'.
